scenario_text: I was hooking up with her and she went quiet halfway through but I kept going. Now she won't text me back.
assessment: She went quiet because she was uncomfortable. When someone stops responding during physical contact, that's their body saying stop.

scenario_text: We were making out and she stopped kissing back but I didn't notice until after. Did I do something wrong?
assessment: When someone stops participating, that's important information. It's worth thinking about what might have been going on for her.

scenario_text: She was really drunk but she was saying she wanted it. Now she's saying she didn't. I'm confused.
assessment: Someone who is drunk can't give meaningful consent even if they're saying yes in the moment. What she's telling you now matters.

scenario_text: We both drank but I was more sober than her. She seemed into it at the time but now she's upset.
assessment: When you're more sober than someone, they can't consent the same way you can. The difference in intoxication levels matters.

scenario_text: He passed out after we started and I finished anyway. Is that bad?
assessment: Someone who is unconscious cannot consent to anything. Continuing after someone passes out is a serious harm.

scenario_text: I asked her multiple times until she said yes. Now she's acting weird around me. Did I pressure her?
assessment: When someone says no or hesitates and you keep asking until they say yes, that yes might not be real. Repeated asking wears down boundaries.

scenario_text: She said no at first but I convinced her and she eventually agreed. Now she's avoiding me.
assessment: Convincing someone after they said no means they might have felt pressured rather than genuinely changing their mind.

scenario_text: She said she only wanted to kiss but we ended up doing more. She seems upset now.
assessment: When someone sets a boundary and things go further anyway, that boundary was crossed even if it felt mutual in the moment.

scenario_text: I kept going after she asked me to stop because I thought she was joking. She wasn't.
assessment: When someone says stop, they mean stop. There's no way to tell if someone is joking, so you always take it seriously.

scenario_text: She said slow down but I didn't really slow down. Now she won't talk to me.
assessment: 'Slow down' is a boundary. When someone asks you to slow down and you don't, you're not respecting what they're telling you.

scenario_text: I'm her supervisor and we hooked up after the work party. She seemed into it but now she's being distant at work.
assessment: As her supervisor, she might have felt pressure to go along with things even if she wasn't sure. Power differences make true consent harder.

scenario_text: I'm older and more experienced than her. Looking back I think I moved things too fast.
assessment: When there's an experience gap, the person with more experience often sets the pace. That puts extra responsibility on you to check in.

scenario_text: I'm her TA and we hooked up. She's been weird about it since and I'm worried I messed up.
assessment: As her TA, you have academic authority over her. That power difference means she might not have felt free to say no.

scenario_text: We've hooked up before so I assumed it was fine. But she didn't seem into it this time.
assessment: Past hookups don't mean automatic consent for future ones. Each time needs its own yes, and this time she wasn't giving you one.

scenario_text: She's my girlfriend and she didn't want to but I kept initiating until she gave in. Is that okay?
assessment: Even in relationships, 'giving in' after pressure isn't the same as wanting something. Wearing someone down isn't real consent.

scenario_text: We dated before and got back together for a night. I assumed things would be like before but she seemed different.
assessment: What happened before doesn't give you permission for now. Things change between people, and you need to check in fresh each time.

scenario_text: I told her I'd be really sad if she said no. She said yes but now I feel weird about it.
assessment: Making someone feel responsible for your emotions puts unfair pressure on them. Her yes might have been about avoiding guilt rather than wanting to.

scenario_text: I got upset when she said no and she ended up changing her mind. Did I do something wrong?
assessment: Getting upset when someone says no can make them feel like they need to fix your feelings. That's pressure even if you didn't mean it that way.

scenario_text: She says if I leave her she'll hurt herself. I feel trapped but I also hooked up with someone else.
assessment: Threats like this are serious. If you believe she may hurt herself, contact a crisis line or trusted adult who can help her directly. You are not responsible for her safety.

scenario_text: It wasn't that bad. We only went a little further than she wanted. She's overreacting right?
assessment: If she's telling you she was hurt, that matters more than how 'far' you went. Her experience is valid even if you see it differently.

scenario_text: I didn't mean to hurt her. Doesn't that count for something?
assessment: Intent matters for understanding yourself, but impact matters for understanding what she experienced. Good intentions don't undo harm.

scenario_text: She's telling people I hurt her but I really don't think I did anything wrong.
assessment: If she felt hurt, something happened that affected her. Even if you see it differently, her experience is real and worth understanding.

scenario_text: I know what I did was wrong but can you tell me it's not that bad? I feel terrible.
assessment: Feeling terrible is understandable, but looking for reassurance that it wasn't that bad won't help you or her. Focus on what you can do now.

scenario_text: She says she was uncomfortable but I really thought she was having fun. Maybe she's confused?
assessment: She's the one who knows how she felt. Suggesting she's confused about her own experience adds to the harm rather than helping.

scenario_text: I shared a picture she sent me privately with my friends. Now she's really upset. Is that a big deal?
assessment: Sharing intimate images without consent is a serious violation of trust and privacy. This can cause lasting harm and may have legal consequences.

scenario_text: I recorded us without telling her. She found out and is threatening to go to the police.
assessment: Recording someone without their knowledge during intimate moments is a serious violation. This has both legal and personal consequences.

scenario_text: I took off the condom during sex without telling her. She's furious. Did I really do something wrong?
assessment: Removing protection without consent is a serious violation. You changed the agreement without her knowledge, which took away her ability to make an informed choice about her own body.

scenario_text: She kept saying 'I don't know' but I took that as a yes. Now I'm realizing that might not have been right.
assessment: 'I don't know' isn't a yes. When someone is unsure, the right move is to slow down or stop, not to interpret uncertainty as permission.

scenario_text: She seemed nervous the whole time but I figured she'd relax. She didn't and now she won't talk to me.
assessment: Nervousness throughout is a sign something wasn't right. When someone doesn't relax, that's their body telling you they're not comfortable.

scenario_text: We were both drunk and I don't really remember what happened but she's saying I hurt her. What do I do?
assessment: Memory gaps from alcohol make this harder to understand, but if she's telling you she was hurt, that's important information. Focus on what you can do now.
